     2â†’  "task_description": "# API Reference Documentation

Generate comprehensive API reference documentation from docstrings covering all public classes, functions, and configurations. Include examples for common use cases.

## Rationale
Proper API documentation is essential for adoption and reduces support burden. The current README is insufficient for production use. This addresses the known gap of limited documentation.

## User Stories
- As a developer, I want to understand available APIs without reading source code
- As a team lead, I want my team to self-serve on Seeknal knowledge

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All public APIs are documented with descriptions, parameters, and return types
- [ ] Each major module has an overview section explaining its purpose
- [ ] Code examples are included for common patterns
- [ ] Documentation is auto-generated from docstrings and stays in sync with code
- [ ] Searchable documentation site is deployed
",
     3â†’  "workflow_type": "feature"
     4â†’}

1â†’# Seeknal Documentation
     2â†’
     3â†’Seeknal is an all-in-one platform for data and AI/ML engineering, providing a feature store implementation with support for both offline (batch) and online (real-time) feature serving.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Table of Contents
     6â†’
     7â†’### Guides
     8â†’1. [Getting Started](./guides/getting-started.md) - Quick setup and first feature store
     9â†’2. [Core Concepts](./guides/core-concepts.md) - Understanding Seeknal architecture
    10â†’3. [CLI Reference](./guides/cli-reference.md) - Command-line interface documentation
    11â†’
    12â†’### Reference
    13â†’4. [API Reference](./api/README.md) - Complete API documentation
    14â†’
    15â†’### Tutorials
    16â†’5. [Tutorials](./tutorials/README.md) - Step-by-step tutorials
    17â†’   - [Basic Feature Store Setup](./tutorials/01-basic-setup.md)
    18â†’   - [Building Feature Pipelines](./tutorials/02-feature-pipelines.md)
    19â†’   - [Point-in-Time Feature Retrieval](./tutorials/03-point-in-time.md)
    20â†’   - [Real-Time Feature Serving](./tutorials/04-online-features.md)
    21â†’   - [Working with DuckDB](./tutorials/05-duckdb-features.md)
    22â†’
    23â†’## Quick Links
    24â†’
    25â†’- [Installation](#installation)
    26â†’- [Project Setup](#project-setup)
    27â†’- [Creating Feature Groups](#creating-feature-groups)
    28â†’- [Feature Serving](#feature-serving)
    29â†’
    30â†’## Installation
    31â†’
    32â†’```bash
    33â†’pip install seeknal
    34â†’```
    35â†’
    36â†’Or for development:
    37â†’
    38â†’```bash
    39â†’git clone https://github.com/your-org/seeknal.git
    40â†’cd seeknal
    41â†’pip install -e .
    42â†’```
    43â†’
    44â†’## Architecture Overview
    45â†’
    46â†’Seeknal follows a modular architecture with the following key components:
    47â†’
    48â†’```
    49â†’seeknal/
    50â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Project          # Top-level project management
    51â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Workspace        # Workspace isolation for teams
    52â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Entity           # Entity definitions (join keys)
    53â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Flow             # Data transformation pipelines
    54â†’â”œâ”€â”€ FeatureGroup     # Feature definitions and metadata
    55â†’â”œâ”€â”€ FeatureStore     # Offline/Online storage backends
    56â†’â””â”€â”€ Tasks            # SparkEngine/DuckDB transformation tasks
    57â†’```
    58â†’
    59â†’## Key Features
    60â†’
    61â†’- **Project & Workspace Management**: Organize features by project and workspace
    62â†’- **Entity-based Design**: Define entities with join keys for consistent feature retrieval
    63â†’- **Flow-based Transformations**: Build transformation pipelines with SparkEngine or DuckDB
    64â†’- **Feature Groups**: Group related features with versioning support
    65â†’- **Offline Store**: Delta Lake or Hive table storage for batch processing
    66â†’- **Online Store**: Low-latency feature serving with DuckDB or file-based storage
    67â†’- **Point-in-Time Joins**: Historical feature retrieval with time-travel support
    68â†’- **Materialization**: Automated feature pipeline execution
    69â†’
    70â†’## Requirements
    71â†’
    72â†’- Python >= 3.11
    73â†’- Apache Spark >= 3.0.0
    74â†’- Delta Lake >= 3.2.0
    75â†’- DuckDB >= 1.1.3 (for local development)
    76â†’

## Complexity Assessment Complete âœ…

I've analyzed the API reference documentation task and created the complexity assessment. Here's my analysis:

### **Complexity: STANDARD** (with research phase)
**Confidence: 85%**

### Key Findings:

**Scope:**
- ~65 Python files to document across the Seeknal codebase
- Estimated 10-15 files need docstring improvements
- 3-5 new config files (documentation tooling + CI/CD pipeline)
- Existing `docs/` directory has guides but no auto-generation setup

**What Makes This Standard (Not Simple):**
- **Research needed**: Must evaluate Sphinx vs MkDocs vs pdoc
- **Infrastructure**: Requires CI/CD pipeline for automated deployment
- **Cross-cutting**: Documentation touches all modules
- **Deployment**: Need to set up searchable documentation hosting (GitHub Pages/Read the Docs)

**What Makes This Standard (Not Complex):**
- **Single integration category**: Documentation tooling only
- **No core infrastructure**: No Docker/database changes
- **Well-defined scope**: Clear requirements, contained to documentation
- **Low risk**: Won't break existing functionality

### Recommended Pipeline:
```
discovery â†’ requirements â†’ research â†’ context â†’ spec_writing â†’ planning â†’ validation
```
(7 phases - includes research for tooling evaluation)

### Risk Assessment:
- **Risk Level**: LOW
- **Main concerns**: Docstring quality variability, tooling choice sustainability
- **Validation**: Minimal mode - verify docs build and deploy successfully

The assessment file has been created at:
`/Users/fitrakacamarga/project/mta/signal/.auto-claude/specs/009-api-reference-documentation/complexity_assessment.json`

entries.detail:
1â†’ 2â†’

3â†’ Seeknal 4â†’

5â†’

6â†’ An all-in-one platform for data and AI/ML engineering 7â†’

8â†’ 9â†’ 10â†’Seeknal is a platform that abstracts away the complexity of data transformation and AI/ML engineering. It is a collection of tools that help you transform data, store it, and use it for machine learning and data analytics. 11â†’ 12â†’Seeknal lets you: 13â†’ 14â†’- **Define** data and feature transformations from raw data sources using Pythonic APIs and YAML. 15â†’- **Register** transformations and feature groups by names and get transformed data and features for various use cases including AI/ML modeling, data engineering, business metrics calculation and more. 16â†’- **Share** transformations and feature groups across teams and company. 17â†’ 18â†’Seeknal is useful in multiple use cases including: 19â†’ 20â†’- AI/ML modeling: computes your feature transformations and incorporates them into your training data, using point-in-time joins to prevent data leakage while supporting the materialization and deployment of your features for online use in production. 21â†’- Data analytics: build data pipelines to extract features and metrics from raw data for Analytics and AI/ML modeling. 22â†’ 23â†’Seeknal is designed as a comprehensive data processing tool that enables you to create an end-to-end pipeline by allowing you to utilize one or more data processing engines (such as Apache Spark combined with DuckDB). To facilitate execution across various engines, Seeknal defines the pipeline in JSON format, which the respective engine processes. In this context, the engines need to support JSON input for the pipeline to function correctly. Since some data processors do not naturally handle YAML input, we enhance these data processors to incorporate this feature, which we refer to as engines. These engines are located in the`engines` folder. 24â†’ 25â†’## Getting started 26â†’We recommend to use uv for installing Seeknal. The following steps are expecting you to have [UV](https://docs.astral.sh/uv/guides/install-python/) installed. 27â†’ 28â†’ 29â†’To install Seeknal, follow these steps: 30â†’ 31â†’1. Download the Seeknal package: 32â†’ 33â†’ - Visit the [releases](https://github.com/mta-tech/seeknal/releases) page and download the latest package. 34â†’ 35â†’2. Extract the Downloaded File: 36â†’ - Unzip the downloaded zip file to your working directory. 37â†’ 38â†’3. Initialize the environment using uv: 39â†’ - Open your terminal and navigate to the directory where you extracted the files. Then, run the following command to initialize the environment: 40â†’ 41â†’ ``` 42â†’ $ cd seeknal_build 43â†’ $ uv venv --python 3.11 44â†’ ``` 45â†’ 46â†’ - Activate the environment: 47â†’ 48â†’ ``` 49â†’ source .venv/bin/activate 50â†’ ``` 51â†’ 52â†’4. Install Seeknal using `uv pip`: 53â†’ ``` 54â†’ uv pip install seeknal--py3-none-any.whl 55â†’ ``` 56â†’ Replace with the actual version number of the wheel file you downloaded. 57â†’ 58â†’5. Verify the Installation: 59â†’ 60â†’ To ensure that Seeknal has been installed correctly, you can run: 61â†’ 62â†’ ``` 63â†’ uv pip show seeknal 64â†’ ``` 65â†’ This command will display information about the installed package, confirming that the installation was successful. 66â†’ 67â†’6. Edit `.env` variable `SEEKNAL_BASE_CONFIG_PATH` and `SEEKNAL_USER_CONFIG_PATH` to point to the directory where you have `config.toml` file. For getting started, we have an example config.toml which you can find inside the `seeknal_build` directory. This case necessary update to the .env to point to the directory. 68â†’ 69â†’ ``` 70â†’ SEEKNAL_BASE_CONFIG_PATH="path/to/seeknal_build" 71â†’ SEEKNAL_USER_CONFIG_PATH="path/to/seeknal_build/config.toml" 72â†’ ``` 73â†’ 74â†’Congratulation! 75â†’Your seeknal has been installed on your machine and ready to use in your projects. To see it in action, check out the `feature-store-demo.ipynb` notebook or see it below. 76â†’ 77â†’## Seeknal in action 78â†’ 79â†’1. Create a data pipeline 80â†’ 81â†’ ```python 82â†’ from seeknal.project import Project 83â†’ from seeknal.flow import ( 84â†’ Flow, 85â†’ FlowInput, 86â†’ FlowOutput, 87â†’ FlowInputEnum, 88â†’ FlowOutputEnum, 89â†’ ) 90â†’ from seeknal.tasks.sparkengine import SparkEngineTask 91â†’ from seeknal.tasks.duckdb import DuckDBTask 92â†’ 93â†’ project = Project(name="my_project", description="My project") 94â†’ project.get_or_create() 95â†’ 96â†’ flow_input = FlowInput(kind=FlowInputEnum.HIVE_TABLE, value="my_df") 97â†’ flow_output = FlowOutput(kind=FlowOutputEnum.SPARK_DATAFRAME) 98â†’ 99â†’ # Develop a pipeline that mixes Spark and DuckDB. 100â†’ task_on_spark = SparkEngineTask().add_sql("SELECT * FROM __THIS__ WHERE day = date_format(current_date(), 'yyyy-MM-dd')") 101â†’ task_on_duckdb = DuckDBTask().add_sql("SELECT id, lat, lon, movement_type, day FROM __THIS__") 102â†’ flow = Flow( 103â†’ name="my_flow", 104â†’ input=flow_input, 105â†’ tasks=[task_on_spark, task_on_duckdb], 106â†’ output=FlowOutput(), 107â†’ ) 108â†’ # save the data pipeline 109â†’ flow.get_or_create() 110â†’ res = flow.run() 111â†’ ``` 112â†’ 113â†’2. Load the saved data pipeline 114â†’ 115â†’ ```python 116â†’ project = Project(name="my_project", description="My project") 117â†’ project.get_or_create() 118â†’ 119â†’ flow = Flow(name="my_flow").get_or_create() 120â†’ res = flow.run() 121â†’ ``` 122â†’ 123â†’3. Save the results to a feature group 124â†’ 125â†’ ```python 126â†’ from datetime import datetime 127â†’ from seeknal.entity import Entity 128â†’ from seeknal.featurestore.feature_group import ( 129â†’ FeatureGroup, 130â†’ Materialization, 131â†’ OfflineMaterialization, 132â†’ OfflineStore, 133â†’ OfflineStoreEnum, 134â†’ FeatureStoreFileOutput, 135â†’ OnlineStore, 136â†’ OnlineStoreEnum, 137â†’ HistoricalFeatures, 138â†’ FeatureLookup, 139â†’ FillNull, 140â†’ GetLatestTimeStrategy, 141â†’ OnlineFeatures, 142â†’ ) 143â†’ 144â†’ # Define a materialization for the offline feature store 145â†’ materialization = Materialization(event_time_col="day", 146â†’ offline_materialization=OfflineMaterialization( 147â†’ store=OfflineStore(kind=OfflineStoreEnum.FILE, 148â†’ name="object_storage", 149â†’ value=FeatureStoreFileOutput(path="s3a://warehouse/feature_store")), 150â†’ mode="overwrite", ttl=None), 151â†’ offline=True) 152â†’ # Define feature group 153â†’ loc_feature_group = FeatureGroup( 154â†’ name="location_feature_group", 155â†’ entity=Entity(name="user_movement", join_keys=["msisdn", "movement_type"]).get_or_create(), 156â†’ materialization=materialization, 157â†’ ) 158â†’ # Attach transformation for create the feature group 159â†’ loc_feature_group.set_flow(flow) 160â†’ 161â†’ # Register all columns as features 162â†’ loc_feature_group.set_features() 163â†’ 164â†’ # Save feature group 165â†’ loc_feature_group.get_or_create() 166â†’ 167â†’ # materialize the feature group to offline feature store 168â†’ loc_feature_group.write( 169â†’ # store features from specific date to the latest 170â†’ feature_start_time=datetime(2019, 3, 5) 171â†’ ) 172â†’ ``` 173â†’ 174â†’4. Load feature group from offline feature store 175â†’ 176â†’ ```python 177â†’ loc_feature_group = FeatureGroup(name="location_feature_group").get_or_create() 178â†’ # lookup for all features of loc_feature_group 179â†’ fs = FeatureLookup(source=loc_feature_group) 180â†’ # impute null to 0.0 181â†’ fillnull = FillNull(value="0.0", dataType="double") 182â†’ # load the features from offline feature store 183â†’ hist = HistoricalFeatures(lookups=[fs], fill_nulls=[fillnull]) 184â†’ df = hist.to_dataframe(feature_start_time=datetime(2019, 3, 5)) 185â†’ ``` 186â†’ 187â†’5. Serve features to online feature store 188â†’ 189â†’ ```python 190â†’ latest_features = hist.using_latest.serve() 191â†’ user_one = Entity(name="user_movement").get_or_create().set_key_values("05X5wBWKN3") 192â†’ user_one_features = latest_features.get_features(keys=[user_one]) 193â†’ ``` 194â†’ 195â†’ 196â†’## Use Turso as Database 197â†’ 198â†’Seeknal uses an SQLite database to store internal data. For production or collaborative use of Seeknal, we suggest using [Turso](https://turso.com/) as your database provider. This allows you to share your Seeknal projects seamlessly across teams and environments, given that it operates using the same database. To set up Turso as your database, edit the `config.toml` file and adjust the `context.database` setting accordingly: 199â†’ 200â†’```toml 201â†’[context.database] 202â†’TURSO_DATABASE_URL = "" 203â†’TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN = "" 204â†’``` 205â†’ 206â†’## Storage Security Best Practices 207â†’ 208â†’Seeknal handles potentially sensitive feature data, so it's important to use secure storage paths. By default, Seeknal stores configuration and data in `~/.seeknal/`, which is a secure, user-specific directory. 209â†’ 210â†’### Why Avoid `/tmp` and World-Writable Directories 211â†’ 212â†’Using `/tmp` or other world-writable directories for data storage creates several security risks: 213â†’ 214â†’| Risk | Description | 215â†’|------|-------------| 216â†’| **Data Exposure** | Other users on the system can read your feature data | 217â†’| **Symlink Attacks** | Malicious users can create symlinks to redirect ... [truncated - full output was 13572 chars]

=== RESEARCH COMPLETE ===

Integrations Researched: 7
- Sphinx: Verified âœ“
- MkDocs: Verified âœ“

- mkdocs-material: Verified âœ“
- mkdocstrings: Verified âœ“

Unverified Claims: 0

Key Findings:
- All documentation tools are standard Python packages with well-established ecosystems
- MkDocs + Material + mkdocstrings is recommended for Seeknal (modern UI, easy to use, great Python support)
- Alternative: Sphinx for industry standard or if PDF/ePub output is required
- Both can deploy to GitHub Pages or Read the Docs
- pdoc is simplest but lacks search and advanced features
- Google-style docstrings recommended for readability and broad tool support

Deployment Options:
1. GitHub Pages (Free, simple, good for MkDocs)
   - Command: mkdocs gh-deploy
   - URL: https://username.github.io/repository/

2. Read the Docs (Free for OSS, advanced features)
   - Automatic builds
   - Version management
   - Search integration

Recommendations:
1. Use MkDocs + Material theme for modern, searchable documentation
2. Deploy to GitHub Pages using 'mkdocs gh-deploy' command
3. Standardize on Google-style docstrings for better readability

```
mkdocs>=1.5.0
mkdocs-material>=9.0.0
mkdocstrings[python]>=0.24.0

```

- Modern, clean UI with built-in search
- Markdown-based (easier than reStructuredText)
- Excellent Python API documentation via mkdocstrings
- Simple deployment: `mkdocs gh-deploy`
- Fast builds with live preview
- Great for the Seeknal project structure

1â†’{
     2â†’  "task_description": "# API Reference Documentation

Generate comprehensive API reference documentation from docstrings covering all public classes, functions, and configurations. Include examples for common use cases.

## Rationale

entries.content:
Excellent! I've completed the planning phase. Here's a summary of what I've created:

## Planning Session Complete âœ…

### Files Created/Updated:

1. **context.json** - Updated with codebase investigation findings:
   - Confirmed source code is in `src/seeknal/` (NO `lib/` directory)
   - Identified Google-style docstring format already in use
   - Documented existing docstring coverage patterns
   - Listed key reference files

2. **implementation_plan.json** - Comprehensive 9-phase plan with 33 subtasks:
   - **Phase 1**: MkDocs Setup (4 subtasks)
   - **Phase 2**: Docstring Audit (3 subtasks)
   - **Phase 3**: Core Module Docstrings (4 subtasks)
   - **Phase 4**: FeatureStore Docstrings (3 subtasks)
   - **Phase 5**: Tasks Module Docstrings (3 subtasks)
   - **Phase 6**: API Reference Pages (4 subtasks)
   - **Phase 7**: Code Examples (5 subtasks)
   - **Phase 8**: Deployment Setup (3 subtasks)
   - **Phase 9**: Final Verification (3 subtasks)

3. **init.sh** - Executable setup script that:
   - Verifies Python 3.11+ and pip
   - Installs documentation dependencies
   - Checks configuration
   - Starts MkDocs development server

4. **build-progress.txt** - Progress tracking document with:
   - Workflow type and rationale
   - Phase summary
   - Investigation findings
   - Parallelism analysis
   - Startup commands

### Key Findings from Investigation:

- **Docstring Format**: Google style (already in use in some classes)
- **Current Coverage**: Partial - classes like `FeatureStoreFileOutput`, `OfflineStore`, and `Entity` have good docstrings, but many methods in `Project`, `Flow`, and other core classes lack documentation
- **No lib/ directory**: Spec mentioned both `src/` and `lib/`, but only `src/seeknal/` exists
- **No existing documentation tooling**: Starting from scratch with MkDocs

### Parallelism Opportunities:

Phases 3, 4, and 5 (docstring enhancement) can run in parallel since they:
- All depend only on Phase 2 (audit)
- Modify different file sets (core vs featurestore vs tasks)
- Could save ~30 minutes if parallelized

However, **recommended workers: 1** due to the sequential nature of documentation work and minimal parallelism benefits.

---

**IMPORTANT**: These planning files are NOT committed to git (they are gitignored). The implementation will be handled by a separate coder agent.

**My planning session is complete. I have NOT started any implementation work.**

Now I understand the pattern. The pattern file uses Google-style docstrings with:
- Class docstrings with "Attributes:" sections
- Method docstrings describing purpose, parameters, returns, and exceptions

**Subtask 3-4 Complete** âœ…

Successfully enhanced Flow class docstrings in `src/seeknal/flow.py`. Added comprehensive documentation following the pattern from `featurestore.py`:

**Classes documented:**
- `FlowOutputEnum` - Enumeration of supported flow output types (8 options)
- `FlowInputEnum` - Enumeration of supported flow input types (5 options)
- `FlowInput` - Configuration for flow input data source with `__call__` method
- `FlowOutput` - Configuration for flow output destination with `__call__` method
- `Flow` - Main data processing pipeline class with all attributes

**Methods documented (Flow class):**
- `__post_init__` - Initialization and snake_case conversion
- `require_saved` - Decorator for saved flow validation
- `set_input_date_col` - Configure date column for filtering
- `run` - Execute the flow pipeline
- `as_dict` / `as_yaml` / `__str__` - Serialization methods
- `from_dict` - Deserialization factory method
- `get_or_create` - Backend persistence
- `list` - List all flows in project

1â†’"""Feature store module for managing and serving ML features.
     2â†’
     3â†’This module provides the core feature store functionality for Seeknal,
     4â†’enabling storage, management, and serving of machine learning features
     5â†’for both offline (batch) and online (real-time) use cases.
     6â†’
     7â†’Key Components:
     8â†’    - FeatureGroup: Define and manage groups of features with customizable
     9â†’      materialization options for offline and online storage.
    10â†’    - FeatureLookup: Specify feature lookups from feature groups with
    11â†’      optional feature selection and exclusion.
    12â†’    - HistoricalFeatures: Retrieve historical feature data with point-in-time
    13â†’      correctness for training ML models.
    14â†’    - OnlineFeatures: Serve features in real-time for model inference with
    15â†’      low-latency access patterns.
    16â†’    - OfflineStore: Configure offline storage backends (Hive tables or Delta files).
    17â†’    - OnlineStore: Configure online storage backends for real-time serving.
    18â†’
    19â†’Storage Backends:
    20â†’    - Hive Tables: Managed table storage with SQL access.

## Summary

Enhanced docstrings in `src/seeknal/featurestore/featurestore.py` for the FeatureStore module. Added comprehensive documentation to:

### Enum Classes
- `OfflineStoreEnum` - Documents offline storage types (HIVE_TABLE, FILE)
- `OnlineStoreEnum` - Documents online storage types
- `FileKindEnum` - Documents file formats (DELTA)

### Dataclasses
- `FeatureStoreHiveTableOutput` - Added class docstring and `to_dict` method docstring
- `FeatureStoreFileOutput.to_dict` - Added method docstring

### OfflineStore Methods
- `get_or_create()` - Documents store retrieval/creation logic
- `list()` - Documents store listing functionality
- `__call__()` - Comprehensive docstring covering write/read operations with all parameters

### OnlineStore Methods
- `__call__()` - Documents write operations and DuckDB reader return
- `delete()` - Documents feature data deletion

### Other Classes
- `FillNull.to_dict()` - Added method docstring
- `Feature.to_dict()` - Documents API-ready dictionary conversion
- `FeatureStore.get_or_create()` - Added abstract method docstring

   119â†’@dataclass
   120â†’class FeatureGroup(FeatureStore):
   121â†’    """
   122â†’    A feature group representing a set of features created from a data source.
   123â†’
   124â†’    A FeatureGroup is a logical grouping of related features that share the same
   125â†’    entity and are typically computed from the same data source (Flow or DataFrame).
   126â†’    It supports both offline and online materialization for feature storage and serving.
   127â†’
   128â†’    Attributes:
   129â†’        name: The unique name of the feature group within the project.
   130â†’        materialization: Configuration for how features are stored and served,
   131â†’            including offline/online storage settings and TTL configurations.
   132â†’        source: The data source for computing features. Can be a Flow pipeline
   133â†’            or a Spark DataFrame. If Flow, output will be set to SPARK_DATAFRAME.
   134â†’        description: Optional human-readable description of the feature group.
   135â†’        features: List of Feature objects to register. If None, all columns
   136â†’            except join_keys and event_time will be registered as features.
   137â†’        tag: Optional list of tags for categorizing and filtering feature groups.
   138â†’        feature_group_id: Unique identifier assigned by the system after creation.
   139â†’        offline_watermarks: List of timestamps indicating when offline data was
   140â†’            materialized. Used for tracking data freshness.
   141â†’        online_watermarks: List of timestamps indicating when online data was
   142â†’            materialized. Used for tracking data freshness.
   143â†’        version: Schema version number for the feature group.
   144â†’        created_at: Timestamp when the feature group was created.
   145â†’        updated_at: Timestamp when the feature group was last updated.
   146â†’        avro_schema: Avro schema definition for the feature data structure.
   147â†’
   148â†’    Example:

   158â†’        >>> fg.set_flow(my_flow).set_features().get_or_create()

entries.detail: File created successfully at: ./test_docstring.py

Task execution framework for data processing pipelines.

This module provides the core task infrastructure for building and executing
data processing pipelines in Seeknal. Tasks are the fundamental units of work
that define data transformations, from simple SQL queries to complex multi-stage
feature engineering pipelines.

Key Components:
    - Task: Abstract base class defining the task interface with methods for
      adding inputs, stages, and executing transformations.
    - SparkEngineTask: Spark-based task implementation for large-scale data
      processing with support for extractors, transformers, aggregators, and
      loaders.
    - DuckDBTask: Lightweight task implementation using DuckDB for smaller
      datasets and local development.

Submodules:
    - sparkengine: Spark-based task execution with ETL components
    - duckdb: DuckDB-based task execution for lightweight processing

Typical Usage:
    Using SparkEngineTask for Spark-based processing::

        from seeknal.tasks.sparkengine import SparkEngineTask

        task = (
            SparkEngineTask(name="feature_pipeline")
            .add_input(table="raw_data.events")
            .set_date_col(date_col="event_date")
            .add_sql("SELECT user_id, COUNT(*) as event_count FROM __THIS__ GROUP BY user_id")
            .add_output(table="features.user_events", partitions=["event_date"])
        )
        result = task.transform()

    Using DuckDBTask for lightweight processing::

        from seeknal.tasks.duckdb import DuckDBTask

        task = (
            DuckDBTask()
            .add_input(path="data/events.parquet")
            .add_sql("SELECT * FROM __THIS__ WHERE status = 'active'")
        )
        result = task.transform()

See Also:
    seeknal.tasks.sparkengine: Spark-based task components and transformers
    seeknal.tasks.duckdb: DuckDB-based task implementation
    seeknal.flow: Pipeline flow orchestration

entries.detail:
from typing import List, Optional, Union
from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

from pyspark.sql import DataFrame, SparkSession
from dataclasses import dataclass
from pyarrow import Table


@dataclass
class Task(ABC):
    """Abstract base class for data processing tasks.

    Task defines the interface for all data processing tasks in seeknal.
    It provides a common structure for defining inputs, transformation stages,
    and outputs. Subclasses implement specific task types (e.g., SparkTask,
    DuckDBTask) with their respective execution engines.

    A task follows a pipeline pattern where data flows through:
    1. Input configuration (add_input)
    2. Transformation stages (transform)
    3. Output configuration

    Attributes:
        is_spark_job: Whether this task runs as a Spark job. If True, the task
            requires a SparkSession for execution.
        kind: The type identifier for this task (e.g., 'spark', 'duckdb').
            Used for serialization and task routing.
        name: Optional name for the task, used for identification and logging.
        description: Optional description explaining the task's purpose.
        common: Optional path to a common YAML configuration file containing
            shared definitions like table schemas or transformations.
        input: Optional dictionary containing input configuration, including
            data sources like Hive tables or DataFrames.
        stages: Optional list of transformation stage dictionaries, each
            defining a step in the data processing pipeline.
        output: Optional dictionary containing output configuration, specifying
            where and how to write the processed data.
        date: Optional date string for time-based filtering or partitioning
            of data during processing.

    Example:
        Subclasses implement specific task types::

            @dataclass
            class SparkTask(Task):
                is_spark_job: bool = True
                kind: str = "spark"

                def add_input(self, hive_table=None, dataframe=None):
                    # Implementation for Spark inputs
                    ...

                def transform(self, spark, chain=True, ...):
                    # Spark transformation logic
                    ...
    """

    is_spark_job: bool
    kind: str
    name: Optional[str] = None

## Summary

**Changes made to `src/seeknal/tasks/sparkengine/sparkengine.py`:**

### Class Docstrings Enhanced:
1. **`Stage`** - Added comprehensive docstring explaining its role as a pipeline stage configuration with Attributes and Example sections
2. **`Stages`** - Added docstring with usage example for batch stage operations
3. **`SparkEngineTask`** - Added detailed class docstring with:

   - Complete Attributes section
   - Multiple code examples (basic pipeline, aggregation)
   - See Also references to related classes/modules

### Method Docstrings Enhanced (30+ methods):
- Input/Output configuration: `add_input`, `add_output`, `set_date_col`, `set_default_input_db`, `set_default_output_db`
- Stage management: `add_stage`, `add_stages`, `update_stage`, `remove_stage`, `insert_stage`
- Convenience methods: `add_sql`, `add_new_column`, `add_filter_by_expr`, `select_columns`, `drop_columns`
- YAML operations: `add_yaml`, `add_yaml_file`, `to_yaml_file`, `print_yaml`, `add_common_yaml`, `add_common_yaml_file`, `print_common_yaml`
- Execution methods: `transform`, `evaluate`, `get_output_dataframe`, `show_output_dataframe`, `is_materialized`, `copy`

All docstrings now follow Google-style conventions with proper `Args`, `Returns`, `Raises`, and `Example` sections as demonstrated in the pattern file.

entries.detail:
1â†’# API Reference
     2â†’
     3â†’This section provides comprehensive API documentation for all Seeknal modules. The documentation is auto-generated from Python docstrings using [mkdocstrings](https://mkdocstrings.github.io/).
     4â†’
     5â†’## Module Overview
     6â†’
     7â†’Seeknal is organized into several key modules, each serving a specific purpose in the data and ML engineering workflow.
     8â†’
     9â†’### Core Modules
    10â†’
    11â†’| Module | Description |
    12â†’|--------|-------------|
    13â†’| [Core](core.md) | Core classes including Project, Entity, Flow, and Context |
    14â†’| [FeatureStore](featurestore.md) | Feature store management, feature groups, and materialization |
    15â†’| [Tasks](tasks.md) | Task definitions for different data processing engines |
    16â†’
    17â†’## Module Hierarchy
    18â†’
    19â†’```
    20â†’seeknal/
    21â†’â”œâ”€â”€ project.py          # Project management
    22â†’â”œâ”€â”€ entity.py           # Entity definitions
    23â†’â”œâ”€â”€ flow.py             # Data pipeline flows
    24â†’â”œâ”€â”€ context.py          # Execution context
    25â†’â”œâ”€â”€ configuration.py    # Configuration management
    26â†’â”œâ”€â”€ featurestore/       # Feature store module
    27â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ featurestore.py # Feature store core
    28â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ feature_group.py# Feature group definitions
    29â†’â”œâ”€â”€ tasks/              # Task definitions
    30â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ base.py         # Base task class
    31â†’â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ sparkengine/    # Spark engine tasks
    32â†’â”‚   â””â”€â”€ duckdb/         # DuckDB tasks
    33â†’â””â”€â”€ exceptions/         # Exception classes
    34â†’```
    35â†’
    36â†’## Quick Navigation
    37â†’
    38â†’### Core Classes
    39â†’
    40â†’- **[Project](core.md#seeknal.project.Project)** - Manage Seeknal projects and their lifecycle
    41â†’- **[Entity](core.md#seeknal.entity.Entity)** - Define entities with join keys for feature stores
    42â†’- **[Flow](core.md#seeknal.flow.Flow)** - Create and manage data transformation pipelines
    43â†’- **[Context](core.md#seeknal.context.Context)** - Execution context and session management
    44â†’
    45â†’### FeatureStore Classes
    46â†’
    47â†’- **[FeatureStore](featurestore.md#seeknal.featurestore.featurestore.FeatureStore)** - Feature store management
    48â†’- **[FeatureGroup](featurestore.md#seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.FeatureGroup)** - Define and materialize feature groups
    49â†’- **[Materialization](featurestore.md#seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.Materialization)** - Configure feature materialization
    50â†’- **[HistoricalFeatures](featurestore.md#seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.HistoricalFeatures)** - Retrieve historical feature values
    51â†’
    52â†’### Task Classes
    53â†’
    54â†’- **[Task](tasks.md#seeknal.tasks.base.Task)** - Base class for all tasks
    55â†’- **[SparkEngineTask](tasks.md#seeknal.tasks.sparkengine.SparkEngineTask)** - Spark-based data processing
    56â†’- **[DuckDBTask](tasks.md#seeknal.tasks.duckdb.DuckDBTask)** - DuckDB-based data processing
    57â†’
    58â†’## Docstring Format
    59â†’
    60â†’All API documentation follows the [Google Python Style Guide](https://google.github.io/styleguide/pyguide.html#38-comments-and-docstrings) for docstrings. Each documented item includes:
    61â†’
    62â†’- **Description**: What the class/function does
    63â†’- **Args/Parameters**: Input parameters with types and descriptions
    64â†’- **Returns**: Return value type and description
    65â†’- **Raises**: Exceptions that may be raised
    66â†’- **Example**: Usage examples where applicable
    67â†’
    68â†’## Filtering
    69â†’
    70â†’!!! note "Private Members"
    71â†’    Private members (those starting with `_`) are excluded from the documentation by default. Only public APIs are documented.
    72â†’

1â†’# FeatureStore API Reference
     2â†’
     3â†’This page documents the FeatureStore module, which provides the core feature store functionality for managing and serving ML features for both offline (batch) and online (real-time) use cases.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Overview
     6â†’
     7â†’The FeatureStore module provides essential classes for feature engineering and serving:
     8â†’
     9â†’| Class | Purpose |
    10â†’|-------|---------|
    11â†’| [`FeatureGroup`](#seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.FeatureGroup) | Define and manage groups of features with customizable materialization |
    12â†’| [`FeatureLookup`](#seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.FeatureLookup) | Specify feature lookups from feature groups |
    13â†’| [`HistoricalFeatures`](#seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.HistoricalFeatures) | Retrieve historical feature data with point-in-time correctness |
    14â†’| [`OnlineFeatures`](#seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.OnlineFeatures) | Serve features in real-time for model inference |
    15â†’| [`OfflineStore`](#seeknal.featurestore.featurestore.OfflineStore) | Configure offline storage backends |
    16â†’| [`OnlineStore`](#seeknal.featurestore.featurestore.OnlineStore) | Configure online storage backends |
    17â†’
    18â†’## FeatureGroup
    19â†’
    20â†’The `FeatureGroup` class is the primary abstraction for defining and managing groups of related features. It handles feature materialization to both offline and online stores.
    21â†’
    22â†’:::seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.FeatureGroup
    23â†’    options:
    24â†’      show_root_heading: false
    25â†’      show_source: true
    26â†’      members_order: source
    27â†’
    28â†’---
    29â†’
    30â†’## FeatureLookup
    31â†’
    32â†’The `FeatureLookup` class specifies how to look up features from a feature group, with optional feature selection and exclusion.
    33â†’
    34â†’:::seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.FeatureLookup
    35â†’    options:
    36â†’      show_root_heading: false
    37â†’      show_source: true
    38â†’      members_order: source
    39â†’
    40â†’---
    41â†’
    42â†’## Materialization
    43â†’
    44â†’The `Materialization` class configures how features are materialized to offline and online stores.
    45â†’
    46â†’:::seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.Materialization
    47â†’    options:
    48â†’      show_root_heading: false
    49â†’      show_source: true
    50â†’      members_order: source
    51â†’
    52â†’---
    53â†’
    54â†’## HistoricalFeatures
    55â†’
    56â†’The `HistoricalFeatures` class retrieves historical feature data with point-in-time correctness for training ML models.
    57â†’
    58â†’:::seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.HistoricalFeatures
    59â†’    options:
    60â†’      show_root_heading: false
    61â†’      show_source: true
    62â†’      members_order: source
    63â†’
    64â†’---
    65â†’
    66â†’## OnlineFeatures
    67â†’
    68â†’The `OnlineFeatures` class serves features in real-time for model inference with low-latency access patterns.
    69â†’
    70â†’:::seeknal.featurestore.feature_group.OnlineFeatures
    71â†’    options:
    72â†’      show_root_heading: false
    73â†’      show_source: true

    76â†’---

1â†’from typing import List, Optional, Union
     2â†’from abc import ABC, abstractmethod
     3â†’
     4â†’from pyspark.sql import DataFrame, SparkSession
     5â†’from dataclasses import dataclass
     6â†’from pyarrow import Table
     7â†’
     8â†’
     9â†’@dataclass
    10â†’class Task(ABC):
    11â†’    """Abstract base class for data processing tasks.
    12â†’
    13â†’    Task defines the interface for all data processing tasks in seeknal.
    14â†’    It provides a common structure for defining inputs, transformation stages,
    15â†’    and outputs. Subclasses implement specific task types (e.g., SparkTask,
    16â†’    DuckDBTask) with their respective execution engines.
    17â†’
    18â†’    A task follows a pipeline pattern where data flows through:
    19â†’    1. Input configuration (add_input)
    20â†’    2. Transformation stages (transform)
    21â†’    3. Output configuration
    22â†’
    23â†’    Attributes:
    24â†’        is_spark_job: Whether this task runs as a Spark job. If True, the task
    25â†’            requires a SparkSession for execution.
    26â†’        kind: The type identifier for this task (e.g., 'spark', 'duckdb').
    27â†’            Used for serialization and task routing.
    28â†’        name: Optional name for the task, used for identification and logging.
    29â†’        description: Optional description explaining the task's purpose.
    30â†’        common: Optional path to a common YAML configuration file containing
    31â†’            shared definitions like table schemas or transformations.
    32â†’        input: Optional dictionary containing input configuration, including
    33â†’            data sources like Hive tables or DataFrames.
    34â†’        stages: Optional list of transformation stage dictionaries, each
    35â†’            defining a step in the data processing pipeline.
    36â†’        output: Optional dictionary containing output configuration, specifying
    37â†’            where and how to write the processed data.
    38â†’        date: Optional date string for time-based filtering or partitioning
    39â†’            of data during processing.
    40â†’
    41â†’    Example:
    42â†’        Subclasses implement specific task types::
    43â†’
    44â†’            @dataclass
    45â†’            class SparkTask(Task):
    46â†’                is_spark_job: bool = True
    47â†’                kind: str = "spark"
    48â†’
    49â†’                def add_input(self, hive_table=None, dataframe=None):
    50â†’                    # Implementation for Spark inputs
    51â†’                    ...
    52â†’
    53â†’                def transform(self, spark, chain=True, ...):
    54â†’                    # Spark transformation logic
    55â†’                    ...
    56â†’    """
    57â†’
    58â†’    is_spark_job: bool
    59â†’    kind: str
    60â†’    name: Optional[str] = None
    61â†’    description: Optional[str] = None
    62â†’    common: Optional[str] = None
    63â†’    input: Optional[dict] = None
    64â†’    stages: Optional[List[dict]] = None
    65â†’    output: Optional[dict] = None
    66â†’    date: Optional[str] = None
    67â†’
    68â†’    @abstractmethod
    69â†’    def add_input(
    70â†’        self,
    71â†’        hive_table: Optional[str] = None,
    72â†’        dataframe: Optional[Union[DataFrame, Table]] = None,
    73â†’    ):
    74â†’        """Add an input data source to the task.
    75â†’
    76â†’        Configures the task with input data from either a Hive table or
    77â†’        an in-memory DataFrame. This method supports method chaining to
    78â†’        allow fluent task configuration.
    79â†’
    80â†’        Args:
    81â†’            hive_table: The fully qualified Hive table name (database.table)
    82â†’                to read data from. Mutually exclusive with dataframe.
    83â†’            dataframe: A PySpark DataFrame or PyArrow Table containing
    84â†’                the input data. Mutually exclusive with hive_table.
    85â†’
    86â†’        Returns:
    87â†’            Task: The current task instance for method chaining.
    88â†’
    89â†’        Example:
    90â†’            Configure input from a Hive table::
    91â†’
    92â†’                task.add_input(hive_table="mydb.customers")
    93â†’
    94â†’            Configure input from a DataFrame::
    95â†’
    96â†’                df = spark.read.parquet("/data/customers")
    97â†’                task.add_input(dataframe=df)
    98â†’        """
    99â†’        return self
   100â†’
   101â†’    @abstractmethod
   102â†’    def transform(
   103â†’        self,
   104â†’        spark: Optional[SparkSession],
   105â†’        chain: bool = True,
   106â†’        materialize: bool = False,
   107â†’        params=None,
   108â†’        filters=None,
   109â†’        date=None,
   110â†’        start_date=None,
   111â†’        end_date=None,
   112â†’    ):
   113â†’        """Execute the task's transformation stages on the input data.
   114â†’
   115â†’        Processes the input data through all configured transformation stages
   116â†’        and returns the resulting DataFrame. The transformation can optionally
   117â†’        be filtered by date ranges.
   118â†’
   119â†’        Args:
   120â†’            spark: SparkSession instance for executing Spark operations.
   121â†’                Required for Spark-based tasks, may be None for other task types.
   122â†’            chain: If True, stages are executed sequentially with each stage
   123â†’                receiving the output of the previous stage. If False, each stage
   124â†’                operates on the original input independently.
   125â†’            materialize: If True, intermediate results are materialized to
   126â†’                improve performance for complex transformations with multiple
   127â†’                downstream operations.
   128â†’            params: Optional dictionary of parameters to pass to transformation
   129â†’                stages, allowing dynamic configuration of transformations.
   130â†’            filters: Optional dictionary of filter conditions to apply to
   131â†’                the data during transformation.
   132â†’            date: Optional date string for single-date filtering.
   133â†’            start_date: Optional start date for date range filtering.
   134â†’                Used with end_date to define a date range.
   135â†’            end_date: Optional end date for date range filtering.
   136â†’                Used with start_date to define a date range.
   137â†’
   138â†’        Returns:
   139â†’            DataFrame: The transformed data as a PySpark DataFrame or
   140â†’                equivalent data structure depending on the task type.
   141â†’
   142â†’        Example:
   143â†’            Execute transformation with date filtering::
   144â†’
   145â†’                result = task.transform(
   146â†’                    spark=spark,
   147â†’                    start_date="2024-01-01",
   148â†’                    end_date="2024-01-31"
   149â†’                )
   150â†’        """
   151â†’        pass
   152â†’
   153â†’    @abstractmethod
   154â†’    def add_common_yaml(self, common_yaml: str):
   155â†’        """Add a common YAML configuration file to the task.
   156â†’
   157â†’        Loads shared configuration definitions from a YAML file, such as
   158â†’        table schemas, column mappings, or reusable transformation templates.
   159â†’        This enables configuration reuse across multiple tasks.
   160â†’
   161â†’        Args:
   162â†’            common_yaml: The filesystem path to the common YAML configuration
   163â†’                file containing shared definitions.
   164â†’
   165â†’        Returns:
   166â†’            Task: The current task instance for method chaining.
   167â†’
   168â†’        Example:
   169â†’            Load common definitions::
   170â†’
   171â†’                task.add_common_yaml("/config/common_schemas.yaml")
   172â†’        """
   173â†’        return self
   174â†’

entries.detail:
1â†’import copy
     2â†’import re
     3â†’import uuid
     4â†’from dataclasses import dataclass, field
     5â†’from datetime import datetime, timedelta
     6â†’from typing import List, Optional, Union
     7â†’
     8â†’import pendulum
     9â†’import typer
    10â†’import yaml
    11â†’from seeknal.context import logger as logger_spark
    12â†’from pyspark.ml.wrapper import JavaWrapper
    13â†’from pyspark.sql import DataFrame, SparkSession
    14â†’
    15â†’from ..base import Task
    16â†’from .aggregators import Aggregator
    17â†’from .extractors import Extractor
    18â†’from .loaders import Loader
    19â†’from .transformers import (
    20â†’    SQL,
    21â†’    AddColumnByExpr,
    22â†’    ClassName,
    23â†’    FeatureTransformer,
    24â†’    FilterByExpr,
    25â†’    PointInTime,
    26â†’    Transformer,
    27â†’)
    28â†’
    29â†’
    30â†’@dataclass
    31â†’class Stage:
    32â†’    """Configuration for a single pipeline stage in a SparkEngine transformation.
    33â†’
    34â†’    A Stage represents one step in a data transformation pipeline. It can contain
    35â†’    a reference to an existing transformation by ID, a custom class with parameters,
    36â†’    or one of several built-in transformation types (feature, aggregator, transformer).
    37â†’
    38â†’    Attributes:
    39â†’        id: Reference ID of a pre-defined transformation available in the project.
    40â†’        class_name: Fully qualified class name of a custom Spark transformation.
    41â†’        params: Parameters dictionary passed to the transformation class.
    42â†’        feature: A FeatureTransformer instance for feature engineering operations.
    43â†’        aggregator: An Aggregator instance for grouping and aggregation operations.
    44â†’        transformer: A Transformer instance for general data transformations.
    45â†’
    46â†’    Example:
    47â†’        Create a stage with a custom transformer::
    48â†’
    49â†’            stage = Stage(
    50â†’                class_name="tech.mta.seeknal.transformers.ColumnRenamed",
    51â†’                params={"inputCol": "old_name", "outputCol": "new_name"}
    52â†’            )
    53â†’
    54â†’        Create a stage referencing an existing transformation::
    55â†’
    56â†’            stage = Stage(id="my_predefined_transform")
    57â†’    """
    58â†’
    59â†’    id: Optional[str] = None
    60â†’    class_name: Optional[str] = None
    61â†’    params: Optional[dict] = None
    62â†’    feature: Optional[FeatureTransformer] = None
    63â†’    aggregator: Optional[Aggregator] = None
    64â†’    transformer: Optional[Transformer] = None
    65â†’
    66â†’
    67â†’@dataclass
    68â†’class Stages:
    69â†’    """Container for multiple pipeline stages.
    70â†’
    71â†’    A Stages object holds a collection of Stage instances that can be added
    72â†’    to a SparkEngineTask pipeline as a batch. This is useful for grouping
    73â†’    related transformations together or reusing common transformation sequences.
    74â†’
    75â†’    Attributes:
    76â†’        stages: List of Stage instances to be executed in order.
    77â†’
    78â†’    Example:
    79â†’        Create a reusable set of stages::
    80â†’
    81â†’            common_stages = Stages(stages=[
    82â†’                Stage(transformer=ColumnRenamed(inputCol="id", outputCol="user_id")),
    83â†’                Stage(transformer=FilterByExpr(expression="status = 'active'"))
    84â†’            ])
    85â†’
    86â†’            task = SparkEngineTask(name="my_task")
    87â†’            task.add_stages(common_stages)
    88â†’    """
    89â†’
    90â†’    stages: List[Stage]
    91â†’
    92â†’
    93â†’@dataclass
    94â†’class SparkEngineTask(Task):
    95â†’    """A Spark-based data transformation task using the Spark Engine framework.
    96â†’
    97â†’    SparkEngineTask provides a fluent interface for building data transformation
    98â†’    pipelines that run on Apache Spark. It supports various input sources (Hive tables,
    99â†’    files, DataFrames), transformation stages (SQL, aggregations, custom transformers),
   100â†’    and output destinations.

    18â†’def extract_widget_type(widget_data):

    20â†’        if not widget_data:
    21â†’            return ""
    22â†’        if isinstance(widget_data, str):
    23â†’            data = json.loads(widget_data)
    24â†’        else:

    26â†’

entries.detail:
1â†’# Examples
     2â†’
     3â†’This section provides practical code examples demonstrating common Seeknal usage patterns. Each example is designed to be self-contained and illustrates best practices for working with the Seeknal platform.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Available Examples
     6â†’
     7â†’| Example | Description |
     8â†’|---------|-------------|
     9â†’| [Initialization](initialization.md) | Project and entity setup, basic configuration |
    10â†’| [FeatureStore](featurestore.md) | Feature group creation, materialization, and retrieval |
    11â†’| [Flows](flows.md) | Data pipeline creation with multiple processing engines |
    12â†’| [Error Handling](error_handling.md) | Exception handling and debugging patterns |
    13â†’| [Configuration](configuration.md) | Config file usage and environment variables |
    14â†’
    15â†’## Quick Start
    16â†’
    17â†’### Basic Workflow
    18â†’
    19â†’The typical Seeknal workflow follows these steps:
    20â†’
    21â†’1. **Initialize** - Set up a project and define entities
    22â†’2. **Transform** - Create flows to transform your data
    23â†’3. **Store** - Materialize features to offline/online stores
    24â†’4. **Retrieve** - Load features for training or serving
    25â†’
    26â†’```python
    27â†’from seeknal.project import Project
    28â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
    29â†’from seeknal.flow import Flow, FlowInput, FlowOutput
    30â†’from seeknal.featurestore.feature_group import FeatureGroup
    31â†’
    32â†’# 1. Initialize
    33â†’project = Project(name="my_project").get_or_create()
    34â†’entity = Entity(name="user", join_keys=["user_id"]).get_or_create()
    35â†’
    36â†’# 2. Transform
    37â†’flow = Flow(name="user_features", input=..., tasks=[...], output=FlowOutput())
    38â†’flow.get_or_create()
    39â†’
    40â†’# 3. Store
    41â†’feature_group = FeatureGroup(name="user_features", entity=entity)
    42â†’feature_group.set_flow(flow)
    43â†’feature_group.get_or_create()
    44â†’feature_group.write()
    45â†’
    46â†’# 4. Retrieve
    47â†’loaded_fg = FeatureGroup(name="user_features").get_or_create()
    48â†’df = loaded_fg.to_dataframe()
    49â†’```
    50â†’
    51â†’## Prerequisites
    52â†’
    53â†’Before running the examples, ensure you have:
    54â†’
    55â†’1. **Seeknal installed**: Follow the [installation guide](../index.md#installation)
    56â†’2. **Configuration set up**: Set the required [environment variables](../index.md#environment-setup)
    57â†’3. **Data processing engine**: Apache Spark or DuckDB depending on your use case
    58â†’
    59â†’## Example Categories
    60â†’
    61â†’### Getting Started
    62â†’
    63â†’If you're new to Seeknal, start with these examples:
    64â†’
    65â†’1. [Initialization](initialization.md) - Learn how to set up projects and entities
    66â†’2. [Configuration](configuration.md) - Understand configuration options
    67â†’
    68â†’### Data Engineering
    69â†’
    70â†’For data pipeline and transformation workflows:
    71â†’
    72â†’1. [Flows](flows.md) - Create multi-engine data pipelines
    73â†’2. [Error Handling](error_handling.md) - Handle errors gracefully
    74â†’
    75â†’### Feature Engineering
    76â†’
    77â†’For ML feature management:
    78â†’
    79â†’1. [FeatureStore](featurestore.md) - Manage features for ML models
    80â†’
    81â†’## Running Examples
    82â†’
    83â†’Most examples can be run in a Python environment with Seeknal installed:
    84â†’
    85â†’```bash
    86â†’# Activate your virtual environment
    87â†’source .venv/bin/activate
    88â†’
    89â†’# Run example scripts
    90â†’python examples/my_example.py
    91â†’```
    92â†’
    93â†’Or in a Jupyter notebook for interactive exploration.
    94â†’
    95â†’## Best Practices
    96â†’
    97â†’!!! tip "Code Patterns"
    98â†’    - Always use `get_or_create()` for idempotent operations
    99â†’    - Set descriptive names for projects, flows, and feature groups
   100â†’    - Use type hints for better code documentation
   101â†’    - Handle exceptions appropriately for production code
   102â†’
   103â†’!!! warning "Production Considerations"
   104â†’    - Never hardcode credentials in your code
   105â†’    - Use environment variables for sensitive configuration
   106â†’    - Test your pipelines with sample data before production runs
   107â†’

1â†’# Initialization
     2â†’
     3â†’This guide demonstrates how to set up and initialize Seeknal projects and entities. These are the foundational building blocks for all Seeknal workflows.
     4â†’
     5â†’## Prerequisites
     6â†’
     7â†’Before running these examples, ensure you have:
     8â†’
     9â†’1. Seeknal installed (see [Installation Guide](../index.md#installation))
    10â†’2. Configuration file set up with valid paths
    11â†’3. Environment variables configured:
    12â†’   ```bash
    13â†’   export SEEKNAL_BASE_CONFIG_PATH="/path/to/config/directory"
    14â†’   export SEEKNAL_USER_CONFIG_PATH="/path/to/config.toml"
    15â†’   ```
    16â†’
    17â†’## Project Setup
    18â†’
    19â†’Projects are the top-level organizational unit in Seeknal. They group related entities, flows, and feature stores together.
    20â†’
    21â†’### Creating a Project
    22â†’
    23â†’```python
    24â†’from seeknal.project import Project
    25â†’
    26â†’# Create a new project with name and description
    27â†’project = Project(
    28â†’    name="my_feature_store",
    29â†’    description="Feature store for customer analytics"
    30â†’)
    31â†’
    32â†’# Save to database (or load if it already exists)
    33â†’project = project.get_or_create()
    34â†’
    35â†’# The project now has an ID assigned
    36â†’print(f"Project ID: {project.project_id}")
    37â†’print(f"Project Name: {project.name}")
    38â†’```
    39â†’
    40â†’!!! note "Name Normalization"
    41â†’    Project names are automatically converted to snake_case. For example,
    42â†’    `"My Feature Store"` becomes `"my_feature_store"`.
    43â†’
    44â†’### Listing All Projects
    45â†’
    46â†’```python
    47â†’from seeknal.project import Project
    48â†’
    49â†’# Display all projects in a formatted table
    50â†’Project.list()
    51â†’```
    52â†’
    53â†’Output:
    54â†’```
    55â†’| name             | description                        | created_at          | updated_at          |
    56â†’|------------------|------------------------------------|---------------------|---------------------|
    57â†’| my_feature_store | Feature store for customer analytics | 2024-01-15 10:30:00 | 2024-01-15 10:30:00 |
    58â†’```
    59â†’
    60â†’### Updating a Project
    61â†’
    62â†’```python
    63â†’from seeknal.project import Project
    64â†’
    65â†’# Load existing project
    66â†’project = Project(name="my_feature_store").get_or_create()
    67â†’
    68â†’# Update the description
    69â†’project = project.update(description="Updated: Customer analytics feature store v2")
    70â†’```
    71â†’
    72â†’### Retrieving a Project by ID
    73â†’
    74â†’```python
    75â†’from seeknal.project import Project
    76â†’
    77â†’# Get project by its unique identifier
    78â†’project = Project.get_by_id(1)
    79â†’print(f"Found project: {project.name}")
    80â†’```
    81â†’
    82â†’## Entity Setup
    83â†’
    84â†’Entities represent domain objects in your feature store (e.g., users, products, transactions). They define the join keys used to associate features with specific instances.
    85â†’
    86â†’### Creating an Entity
    87â†’
    88â†’```python
    89â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
    90â†’
    91â†’# Create a basic entity with a single join key
    92â†’user_entity = Entity(
    93â†’    name="customer",
    94â†’    join_keys=["customer_id"],
    95â†’    description="Customer entity for retail features"
    96â†’)
    97â†’user_entity = user_entity.get_or_create()
    98â†’
    99â†’print(f"Entity ID: {user_entity.entity_id}")
   100â†’print(f"Join Keys: {user_entity.join_keys}")
   101â†’```
   102â†’
   103â†’### Entity with Multiple Join Keys
   104â†’
   105â†’For composite keys, specify multiple columns in the `join_keys` list:
   106â†’
   107â†’```python
   108â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   109â†’
   110â†’# Entity with composite key (multiple columns)
   111â†’order_entity = Entity(
   112â†’    name="order_item",
   113â†’    join_keys=["order_id", "product_id"],
   114â†’    description="Order item entity for transaction features"
   115â†’)
   116â†’order_entity = order_entity.get_or_create()
   117â†’```
   118â†’
   119â†’### Entity with PII Keys
   120â†’
   121â†’Mark columns containing personally identifiable information for compliance tracking:
   122â†’
   123â†’```python
   124â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   125â†’
   126â†’# Entity with PII keys for data privacy compliance
   127â†’customer_entity = Entity(
   128â†’    name="customer_profile",
   129â†’    join_keys=["customer_id"],
   130â†’    pii_keys=["email", "phone_number", "address"],
   131â†’    description="Customer profile with PII tracking"
   132â†’)
   133â†’customer_entity = customer_entity.get_or_create()
   134â†’```
   135â†’
   136â†’!!! warning "PII Handling"
   137â†’    PII keys are used for data privacy compliance and tracking. Ensure you
   138â†’    follow your organization's data governance policies when handling PII data.
   139â†’
   140â†’### Listing All Entities
   141â†’
   142â†’```python
   143â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   144â†’
   145â†’# Display all registered entities
   146â†’Entity.list()
   147â†’```
   148â†’
   149â†’Output:
   150â†’```
   151â†’| name             | join_keys              | pii_keys                    | description                    |
   152â†’|------------------|------------------------|-----------------------------|--------------------------------|
   153â†’| customer         | customer_id            | None                        | Customer entity for retail     |
   154â†’| order_item       | order_id,product_id    | None                        | Order item entity              |
   155â†’| customer_profile | customer_id            | email,phone_number,address  | Customer profile with PII      |
   156â†’```
   157â†’
   158â†’### Updating an Entity
   159â†’
   160â†’```python
   161â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   162â†’
   163â†’# Load and update entity
   164â†’entity = Entity(name="customer").get_or_create()
   165â†’entity.update(
   166â†’    description="Updated customer entity description",
   167â†’    pii_keys=["email"]  # Add PII tracking
   168â†’)
   169â†’```
   170â†’
   171â†’!!! note "Join Keys Are Immutable"
   172â†’    Join keys cannot be modified after entity creation because they define
   173â†’    the entity's identity. To change join keys, create a new entity.
   174â†’
   175â†’### Setting Key Values for Point Lookups
   176â†’
   177â†’When retrieving features for a specific entity instance, use `set_key_values()`:
   178â†’
   179â†’```python
   180â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   181â†’
   182â†’# Load entity
   183â†’entity = Entity(name="order_item", join_keys=["order_id", "product_id"]).get_or_create()
   184â†’
   185â†’# Set specific values for lookup
   186â†’entity = entity.set_key_values("ORD-12345", "PROD-6789")
   187â†’
   188â†’# Access the key-value mapping
   189â†’print(entity.key_values)
   190â†’# Output: {'order_id': 'ORD-12345', 'product_id': 'PROD-6789'}
   191â†’```
   192â†’
   193â†’## Complete Initialization Example
   194â†’
   195â†’Here's a complete example setting up a project with multiple entities:
   196â†’
   197â†’```python
   198â†’from seeknal.project import Project
   199â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   200â†’
   201â†’# Step 1: Create and initialize the project
   202â†’project = Project(
   203â†’    name="ecommerce_features",
   204â†’    description="Feature store for e-commerce recommendation engine"
   205â†’)
   206â†’project = project.get_or_create()
   207â†’print(f"Project initialized: {project.name} (ID: {project.project_id})")
   208â†’
   209â†’# Step 2: Create customer entity
   210â†’customer = Entity(
   211â†’    name="customer",
   212â†’    join_keys=["customer_id"],
   213â†’    pii_keys=["email"],
   214â†’    description="Customer entity for user-based features"
   215â†’)
   216â†’customer = customer.get_or_create()
   217â†’print(f"Customer entity created: {customer.name}")
   218â†’
   219â†’# Step 3: Create product entity
   220â†’product = Entity(
   221â†’    name="product",
   222â†’    join_keys=["product_id"],
   223â†’    description="Product catalog entity"
   224â†’)
   225â†’product = product.get_or_create()
   226â†’print(f"Product entity created: {product.name}")
   227â†’
   228â†’# Step 4: Create interaction entity (composite key)
   229â†’interaction = Entity(
   230â†’    name="customer_product_interaction",
   231â†’    join_keys=["customer_id", "product_id"],
   232â†’    description="Customer-product interaction for collaborative filtering"
   233â†’)
   234â†’interaction = interaction.get_or_create()
   235â†’print(f"Interaction entity created: {interaction.name}")
   236â†’
   237â†’# View all entities
   238â†’print("\nAll registered entities:")
   239â†’Entity.list()
   240â†’```
   241â†’
   242â†’## Idempotent Operations
   243â†’
   244â†’The `get_or_create()` pattern ensures idempotent operations:
   245â†’
   246â†’```python
   247â†’from seeknal.project import Project
   248â†’
   249â†’# First call creates the project
   250â†’project1 = Project(name="my_project").get_or_create()
   251â†’print(f"Project ID: {project1.project_id}")
   252â†’
   253â†’# Second call retrieves the existing project (no duplicate created)
   254â†’project2 = Project(name="my_project").get_or_create()
   255â†’print(f"Same Project ID: {project2.project_id}")
   256â†’
   257â†’# Both variables reference the same project
   258â†’assert project1.project_id == project2.project_id
   259â†’```
   260â†’
   261â†’This pattern is safe to run multiple times without side effects, making it ideal for deployment scripts and CI/CD pipelines.
   262â†’
   263â†’## Error Handling
   264â†’
   265â†’Handle common initialization errors gracefully:
   266â†’
   267â†’```python
   268â†’from seeknal.project import Project
   269â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   270â†’from seeknal.exceptions import ProjectNotFoundError, EntityNotFoundError, EntityNotSavedError
   271â†’
   272â†’# Handle project not found
   273â†’try:
   274â†’    project = Project.get_by_id(9999)  # Non-existent ID
   275â†’except ProjectNotFoundError as e:
   276â†’    print(f"Project error: {e}")
   277â†’
   278â†’# Handle entity not saved
   279â†’try:
   280â†’    entity = Entity(name="test_entity", join_keys=["id"])
   281â†’    # Attempting to update without calling get_or_create() first
   282â†’    entity.update(description="New description")
   283â†’except EntityNotSavedError as e:
   284â†’    print(f"Entity must be saved first: {e}")
   285â†’```
   286â†’
   287â†’See [Error Handling](error_handling.md) for more comprehensive exception

entries.detail:
# FeatureStore

This guide demonstrates how to create and manage feature groups in Seeknal's Feature Store. Feature groups are the primary way to organize, store, and serve features for machine learning models.

## Prerequisites

Before running these examples, ensure you have:

1. Seeknal installed (see [Installation Guide](../index.md#installation))
2. Project and Entity configured (see [Initialization](initialization.md))
3. A SparkSession active (Seeknal will create one if needed)
4. Environment variables configured:
   ```bash
   export SEEKNAL_BASE_CONFIG_PATH="/path/to/config/directory"
   export SEEKNAL_USER_CONFIG_PATH="/path/to/config.toml"
   ```

## Core Concepts

### Feature Groups

A **FeatureGroup** is a logical grouping of related features that:

- Share the same entity (e.g., user, product, transaction)
- Are typically computed from the same data source
- Support both offline (batch) and online (real-time) materialization

### Materialization

**Materialization** is the process of computing and storing features. Seeknal supports:

- **Offline Store**: For batch processing and training (Delta Lake format)
- **Online Store**: For low-latency feature serving (Parquet files)

## Creating a Basic Feature Group

### Step 1: Set Up Project and Entity

```python
from seeknal.project import Project
from seeknal.entity import Entity

# Initialize project
project = Project(
    name="recommendation_engine",
    description="Features for product recommendations"
)
project = project.get_or_create()

# Create entity
user_entity = Entity(
    name="user",
    join_keys=["user_id"],
    description="User entity for recommendation features"
)
user_entity = user_entity.get_or_create()
```

### Step 2: Create a Data Flow

```python
from seeknal.flow import Flow, FlowInput, FlowOutput, FlowOutputEnum
from seeknal.tasks.sparkengine import SparkEngineTask

# Define input source
flow_input = FlowInput(
    path="/data/user_activity.parquet",
    format="parquet"
)

# Create transformation task
transform_task = SparkEngineTask().add_stage(
    class_name="tech.mta.seeknal.transformers.SelectExpr",
    params={
        "expressions": [
            "user_id",
            "event_date",
            "COUNT(*) as activity_count",
            "SUM(purchase_amount) as total_spend"
        ]
    }
)

# Build the flow
user_activity_flow = Flow(
    name="user_activity_features",
    input=flow_input,
    tasks=[transform_task],
    output=FlowOutput(kind=FlowOutputEnum.SPARK_DATAFRAME)
)
user_activity_flow = user_activity_flow.get_or_create()
```

### Step 3: Create Feature Group with Materialization

```python
from seeknal.featurestore import FeatureGroup, Materialization

# Configure materialization settings
materialization = Materialization(

    72â†’### Retrieving a Project by ID
    73â†’
    74â†’```python
    75â†’from seeknal.project import Project
    76â†’
    77â†’# Get project by its unique identifier
    78â†’project = Project.get_by_id(1)
    79â†’print(f"Found project: {project.name}")
    80â†’```
    81â†’
    82â†’## Entity Setup
    83â†’
    84â†’Entities represent domain objects in your feature store (e.g., users, products, transactions). They define the join keys used to associate features with specific instances.
    85â†’
    86â†’### Creating an Entity
    87â†’
    88â†’```python
    89â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
    90â†’
    91â†’# Create a basic entity with a single join key
    92â†’user_entity = Entity(
    93â†’    name="customer",
    94â†’    join_keys=["customer_id"],
    95â†’    description="Customer entity for retail features"
    96â†’)
    97â†’user_entity = user_entity.get_or_create()
    98â†’
    99â†’print(f"Entity ID: {user_entity.entity_id}")
   100â†’print(f"Join Keys: {user_entity.join_keys}")
   101â†’```
   102â†’
   103â†’### Entity with Multiple Join Keys
   104â†’
   105â†’For composite keys, specify multiple columns in the `join_keys` list:
   106â†’
   107â†’```python
   108â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   109â†’
   110â†’# Entity with composite key (multiple columns)
   111â†’order_entity = Entity(
   112â†’    name="order_item",
   113â†’    join_keys=["order_id", "product_id"],
   114â†’    description="Order item entity for transaction features"
   115â†’)
   116â†’order_entity = order_entity.get_or_create()
   117â†’```
   118â†’
   119â†’### Entity with PII Keys
   120â†’
   121â†’Mark columns containing personally identifiable information for compliance tracking:
   122â†’
   123â†’```python
   124â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   125â†’
   126â†’# Entity with PII keys for data privacy compliance
   127â†’customer_entity = Entity(
   128â†’    name="customer_profile",
   129â†’    join_keys=["customer_id"],
   130â†’    pii_keys=["email", "phone_number", "address"],
   131â†’    description="Customer profile with PII tracking"
   132â†’)
   133â†’customer_entity = customer_entity.get_or_create()
   134â†’```
   135â†’
   136â†’!!! warning "PII Handling"
   137â†’    PII keys are used for data privacy compliance and tracking. Ensure you
   138â†’    follow your organization's data governance policies when handling PII data.
   139â†’
   140â†’### Listing All Entities
   141â†’
   142â†’```python
   143â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   144â†’
   145â†’# Display all registered entities
   146â†’Entity.list()
   147â†’```
   148â†’
   149â†’Output:
   150â†’```
   151â†’| name             | join_keys              | pii_keys                    | description                    |
   152â†’|------------------|------------------------|-----------------------------|--------------------------------|
   153â†’| customer         | customer_id            | None                        | Customer entity for retail     |
   154â†’| order_item       | order_id,product_id    | None                        | Order item entity              |
   155â†’| customer_profile | customer_id            | email,phone_number,address  | Customer profile with PII      |
   156â†’```
   157â†’
   158â†’### Updating an Entity
   159â†’
   160â†’```python
   161â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   162â†’
   163â†’# Load and update entity
   164â†’entity = Entity(name="customer").get_or_create()
   165â†’entity.update(
   166â†’    description="Updated customer entity description",
   167â†’    pii_keys=["email"]  # Add PII tracking
   168â†’)
   169â†’```
   170â†’
   171â†’!!! note "Join Keys Are Immutable"
   172â†’    Join keys cannot be modified after entity creation because they define
   173â†’    the entity's identity. To change join keys, create a new entity.
   174â†’
   175â†’### Setting Key Values for Point Lookups
   176â†’
   177â†’When retrieving features for a specific entity instance, use `set_key_values()`:
   178â†’
   179â†’```python
   180â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   181â†’
   182â†’# Load entity
   183â†’entity = Entity(name="order_item", join_keys=["order_id", "product_id"]).get_or_create()
   184â†’
   185â†’# Set specific values for lookup
   186â†’entity = entity.set_key_values("ORD-12345", "PROD-6789")
   187â†’
   188â†’# Access the key-value mapping
   189â†’print(entity.key_values)
   190â†’# Output: {'order_id': 'ORD-12345', 'product_id': 'PROD-6789'}
   191â†’```
   192â†’
   193â†’## Complete Initialization Example
   194â†’
   195â†’Here's a complete example setting up a project with multiple entities:
   196â†’
   197â†’```python
   198â†’from seeknal.project import Project
   199â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   200â†’
   201â†’# Step 1: Create and initialize the project
   202â†’project = Project(
   203â†’    name="ecommerce_features",
   204â†’    description="Feature store for e-commerce recommendation engine"
   205â†’)
   206â†’project = project.get_or_create()
   207â†’print(f"Project initialized: {project.name} (ID: {project.project_id})")
   208â†’
   209â†’# Step 2: Create customer entity
   210â†’customer = Entity(
   211â†’    name="customer",
   212â†’    join_keys=["customer_id"],
   213â†’    pii_keys=["email"],
   214â†’    description="Customer entity for user-based features"
   215â†’)
   216â†’customer = customer.get_or_create()
   217â†’print(f"Customer entity created: {customer.name}")
   218â†’
   219â†’# Step 3: Create product entity
   220â†’product = Entity(
   221â†’    name="product",
   222â†’    join_keys=["product_id"],
   223â†’    description="Product catalog entity"
   224â†’)
   225â†’product = product.get_or_create()
   226â†’print(f"Product entity created: {product.name}")
   227â†’
   228â†’# Step 4: Create interaction entity (composite key)
   229â†’interaction = Entity(
   230â†’    name="customer_product_interaction",
   231â†’    join_keys=["customer_id", "product_id"],
   232â†’    description="Customer-product interaction for collaborative filtering"
   233â†’)
   234â†’interaction = interaction.get_or_create()
   235â†’print(f"Interaction entity created: {interaction.name}")
   236â†’
   237â†’# View all entities
   238â†’print("\nAll registered entities:")
   239â†’Entity.list()
   240â†’```
   241â†’
   242â†’## Idempotent Operations
   243â†’
   244â†’The `get_or_create()` pattern ensures idempotent operations:
   245â†’
   246â†’```python
   247â†’from seeknal.project import Project
   248â†’
   249â†’# First call creates the project
   250â†’project1 = Project(name="my_project").get_or_create()
   251â†’print(f"Project ID: {project1.project_id}")
   252â†’
   253â†’# Second call retrieves the existing project (no duplicate created)
   254â†’project2 = Project(name="my_project").get_or_create()
   255â†’print(f"Same Project ID: {project2.project_id}")
   256â†’
   257â†’# Both variables reference the same project
   258â†’assert project1.project_id == project2.project_id
   259â†’```
   260â†’
   261â†’This pattern is safe to run multiple times without side effects, making it ideal for deployment scripts and CI/CD pipelines.
   262â†’
   263â†’## Error Handling
   264â†’
   265â†’Handle common initialization errors gracefully:
   266â†’
   267â†’```python
   268â†’from seeknal.project import Project
   269â†’from seeknal.entity import Entity
   270â†’from seeknal.exceptions import ProjectNotFoundError, EntityNotFoundError, EntityNotSavedError
   271â†’
   272â†’# Handle project not found
   273â†’try:
   274â†’    project = Project.get_by_id(9999)  # Non-existent ID
   275â†’except ProjectNotFoundError as e:
   276â†’    print(f"Project error: {e}")
   277â†’
   278â†’# Handle entity not saved
   279â†’try:
   280â†’    entity = Entity(name="test_entity", join_keys=["id"])
   281â†’    # Attempting to update without calling get_or_create() first
   282â†’    entity.update(description="New description")
   283â†’except EntityNotSavedError as e:
   284â†’    print(f"Entity must be saved first: {e}")
   285â†’```
   286â†’
   287â†’See [Error Handling](error_handling.md) for more comprehensive exception 

... [truncated - full output was 11018 chars]
